What are the options for response by the national healthcare authorities?

- robust monitoring
- expanded testing
- proper contact tracing
- prompt identification of clusters
- strong #RiskCommunication reminding citizens that the #pandemic is not over.

https://t.co/BR5BYugM6S https://t.co/bSiiAK90KS

#ECDC Director Andrea #Ammon:

"(...) At an individual level, we should maintain #PhysicalDistancing whenever possible, remain vigilant and continue exercising #HandHygiene.

Some countries report resurgence of cases or localised outbreaks. Reasons vary:

- changes in case ascertainment (e.g. increased testing,
case definition change)
- genuine increases in transmission
- importation of cases

@KatyLLock @stpkav @JNRaeside @MitchBenn @OurWorldInData These must have been retro-corrections. We need to put them in this way, as we depend on numbers reported to us from the Member States. These tend to sometime correct or change the way of reporting and we need to follow suit.

5. Arrival airport:
-> practice #HandHygiene, #CoughEtiquette, wear a #FaceMask
-> collect your luggage, leave the terminal as soon as possible
-> reduce the risk of #COVID19 transmission by minimising interaction with people in the terminal

Full report: https://t.co/PvYkCqCkiQ https://t.co/KG3HMvdxRW

4. On the plane
-> practice #HandHygiene, #CoughEtiquette, wear a #FaceMask
-> watch the cabin safety demo, for specific instructions for your flight!
-> feeling ill? Inform the crew & seek medical care
-> limit your movement in the cabin

https://t.co/PvYkCqCkiQ
#COVID19 https://t.co/UPKDjlPmQD

3. Departure airport:
-> questions or concerns ? Ask the staff!
-> bring all you need for the trip, have all your documents handy
-> practice #PhysicalDistancing, wear a #FaceMask (you may be refused boarding when failing to do so)
-> comply with thermal screening

#COVID19 https://t.co/OoSwdtPCst

2. When going to the airport:
-> be aware only travellers may enter the terminal!
-> leave enough time for checks & new procedures
-> follow the #CoughEtiquette and wear a #FaceMask to protect yourself and your fellow passengers.

Report: https://t.co/PvYkCqCkiQ
#COVID19 https://t.co/J8ZlLlIbLw

#Nurses and #midwives play a vital role in providing health services by devoting their lives to caring for mothers and children; giving lifesaving immunisations & health advice; looking after older people and meeting everyday essential health needs.

More: https://t.co/ehakkVb37I

#ECDC supports this campaign and highlights the importance of infection prevention and control measures as one of the main strategies to tackle the growing threat posed by #AntibioticResistance. https://t.co/KOG1ANL750

“#Nurses and #Midwives, clean care is in your hands!”: with this slogan, the #WHO calls on nurses, midwives, policymakers, infection prevention and control leaders, patients and families to be inspired by the global movement to take action. https://t.co/5tm59DMGKx

A large percentage of these infections are preventable by improving #HandHygiene practices.

It is the ‘single most important measure’ to prevent transmission of bacteria in hospitals and other healthcare settings, according to the @WHO! https://t.co/eRbgvxPgoY

Healthcare-associated infections, including those caused by bacteria resistant to #antibiotics, are a growing public health problem in Europe.

75% of the health burden of infections with bacteria resistant to antibiotics in Europe is due to healthcare-associated infections. https://t.co/cRQ9aHoq76

Today is the World #HandHygiene day!

We have already highlighted the importance of proper hand washing in times of #COVID19 by everyone, but the #WorldHandHygieneDay on healthcare settings!

Read more: https://t.co/ehakkVb37I https://t.co/BZvYB3uM83

On 2.02, #ECDC issued its first guidance, on infection prevention and control for the care of patients with #SARSCoV2 in healthcare settings.

Since then, we produced around 25 pieces of guidance & advice, not counting numerous videos, infographics, leaflets and other materials. https://t.co/tKce4YuYId

On 17.01 we issued the first rapid risk assessment, where we assessed the risk for travellers, importation and further spread in the EU, based on the facts known to #ECDC at the time of publication. Up to now ECDC has issued nine rapid risk assessments.

#COVID19 https://t.co/wMZSPwYxvM

Andrea #Ammon:

On 9.01, we issued the first threat assessment brief, warning about a cluster of 27 pneumonia cases of unknown aetiology in China. We cautioned that the Chinese New Year celebrations would increase the risk of possible cases arriving in the EU.

#COVID19 https://t.co/DDStof1VDz

#ECDC Epidemic Intelligence caught the first signals of an outbreak of pneumonia cases in Wuhan on 31.12 and reached out to China CDC and WHO.

Later that day, we received the alert from China CDC. Little was known in the beginning, but we kept monitoring the situation.

#COVID19 https://t.co/o1dBvPMVrO

#ECDC reacted as soon as we became aware of the threat and issued assessments and cautionary advice multiple times, as early as 9.01

We assess the risk according to a standard methodology, taking into account various parameters and addressing several questions.
#COVID19 https://t.co/7I1V4hrzlc

We are #LIVE now!

#ECDC Director - Andrea Ammon joins the #COVID19 discussion hosted by the European Commission Representation in Austria - @EUKommWien.
